flags.title: From CRAFT
flags.text: This project first appeared on the pages of CRAFT or on Craftzine.

guide.introduction: Construct a basic long necktie with stripes to represent your favorite value of resistor - fashion inspired by the electronics bench! Learn to work with slippery fabrics cut on the bias.
guide.introduction_rendered:
Construct a basic long necktie with stripes to represent your favorite value of resistor - fashion inspired by the electronics bench! Learn to work with slippery fabrics cut on the bias.

Relevant parts
  • Fusible interfacing
  • Satin tie fabric
Tools
  • Cutting mat / work surface
  • Iron
  • Needle and thread
  • Rotary cutter
  • Scissors
  • Sewing machine
  • Sewing pins

parts.notes: in colors to match your favorite resistor

lines.text: Gather materials and tools.
lines.text_raw: Gather materials and tools.

lines.text: There are many free tie patterns available online. I like the Purl Bee's print-at-home pattern.
lines.text_raw: There are many free tie patterns available online. I like the [http://www.purlbee.com/fathers-day-ties/|Purl Bee's print-at-home pattern].

lines.text: Cut stripes from each colored fabric with the grain and reassemble a single piece of striped fabric.
lines.text_raw: Cut stripes from each colored fabric with the grain and reassemble a single piece of striped fabric.

lines.text: I used a serger to keep things tidy.
lines.text_raw: I used a serger to keep things tidy.

lines.text: Press the seam allowances towards the colored stripes.
lines.text_raw: Press the seam allowances towards the colored stripes.

lines.text: My stripes are a half inch wide with a quarter inch of seam allowance on each edge, and I left about 5 inches at the end of the "champagne" colored fabric that's meant to represent the ceramic body of the resistor.
lines.text_raw: My stripes are a half inch wide with a quarter inch of seam allowance on each edge, and I left about 5 inches at the end of the "champagne" colored fabric that's meant to represent the ceramic body of the resistor.

lines.text: Fold your fabric into a triangle to find the bias-- a 45 degree angle from the grain of the woven threads.
lines.text_raw: Fold your fabric into a triangle to find the bias-- a 45 degree angle from the grain of the woven threads.

lines.text: Lay out and cut the three main tie pattern pieces along this bias. A tie cut with the grain would try to twist on itself instead of draping flat and straight.
lines.text_raw: Lay out and cut the three main tie pattern pieces along this bias. A tie cut with the grain would try to twist on itself instead of draping flat and straight.

lines.text: It's less important that the two lining pieces be cut on the bias, so try it both ways if you're curious about the effects.
lines.text_raw: It's less important that the two lining pieces be cut on the bias, so try it both ways if you're curious about the effects.

lines.text: Press iron-on interfacing to the wrong side of the cut pattern pieces.
lines.text_raw: Press iron-on interfacing to the wrong side of the cut pattern pieces.

lines.text: I used parchment paper to protect my ironing surface from sticky residue.
lines.text_raw: I used parchment paper to protect my ironing surface from sticky residue.

lines.text: Cut the pattern pieces from the interfacing.
lines.text_raw: Cut the pattern pieces from the interfacing.

lines.text: Use a low iron setting for synthetics with no steam.
lines.text_raw: Use a low iron setting for synthetics with no steam.

lines.text: Pin pattern pieces to line up at 1/2" seam allowance.
lines.text_raw: Pin pattern pieces to line up at 1/2" seam allowance.

lines.text: Use a straight stitch to sew the seams and press them flat with your iron.
lines.text_raw: Use a straight stitch to sew the seams and press them flat with your iron.

lines.text: Press up each point about 1/4 inch.
lines.text_raw: Press up each point about 1/4 inch.

lines.text: Press a 1/4 inch seam allowance along the nearby edges of both main and lining pieces.
lines.text_raw: Press a 1/4 inch seam allowance along the nearby edges of both main and lining pieces.

lines.text: Pin the linings to the main tie with the recently pressed edges hidden inside.
lines.text_raw: Pin the linings to the main tie with the recently pressed edges hidden inside.

lines.text: Use an invisible stitch to secure these lining pieces to the main tie.
lines.text_raw: Use an invisible stitch to secure these lining pieces to the main tie.

lines.text: Press a 1/4 inch seam allowance along both long edges of the tie.
lines.text_raw: Press a 1/4 inch seam allowance along both long edges of the tie.

lines.text: If your tie fabric is very thin, install a piece of thick collar interfacing inside this fold with the ends tucked behind the lining.
lines.text_raw: If your tie fabric is very thin, install a piece of thick collar interfacing inside this fold with the ends tucked behind the lining.

lines.text: Fold these edges once more to meet in the center back of the tie.
lines.text_raw: Fold these edges once more to meet in the center back of the tie.

lines.text: Press this fold along the length of the tie with your iron.
lines.text_raw: Press this fold along the length of the tie with your iron.

lines.text: Use an invisible ladder stitch to join the seam along the length of the tie.
lines.text_raw: Use an invisible ladder stitch to join the seam along the length of the tie.

lines.text: Wear to your next formal occasion.
lines.text_raw: Wear to your next formal occasion.

lines.text: A high-quality tie is all about the details, so take your time and you'll end up with a really nice finished product.
lines.text_raw: A high-quality tie is all about the details, so take your time and you'll end up with a really nice finished product.

guide.title: Resistor Necktie
